column1: Oceanside is a coastal city on California's South Coast. It is the third-largest city in San Diego County
column2: California. The city had a population of 167
column3: 086 at the 2010 census. Together with Carlsbad and Vista
column4: it forms a tri-city area. Oceanside is just south of Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton.

column2: the first European explorers arrived in 1769. Spanish missionaries under Father Junipero Serra founded Mission San Luis Rey de Francia on a former site of a Luiseño Indian village on the banks of the San Luis Rey River. In the early 19th century
column3: the introduction of farming and grazing changed the landscape of what would become Oceanside. The area—like all of California—was under Spanish rule
column4: then in 1821 under Mexican rule

column2: Andrew Jackson Myers lived in San Joaquin County.  A native of LaSalle County
column4: he returned in the late 1880s and lived in San Luis Rey.  In 1882 Myers moved on the land that was the original town site for Oceanside.  A patent for the land was issued in 1883 by the federal government. It was incorporated on July 3
column5: 1888. The city hall as of the early 21st century stands on the former Myers homestead.

column1: The town post office contains an oil-on-canvas mural
column3: painted in 1937 by Elsie Seeds. Federally commissioned murals were produced from 1934 to 1943 in the United States through the Section of Painting and Sculpture
column4: later called the Section of Fine Arts

column6: Oceanside was a beach town devoted to activities on a 6-mile (10 km) stretch of beaches. Residential areas like downtown (built in the 1890s)
column8: and developments east of Interstate 5 (built after World War II) are preserved and remodeled when these houses are considered to have historical value. Since the establishment of Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton in 1942
column9: Oceanside has been home to U.S. armed forces personnel
column10: and the wartime industry of WWII and the 1950s had an ammunition manufacturing facility in the city.In 1970
column11: the Census Bureau reported city's population as 91.0% white
column13: the main focus of Oceanside was suburban development and a choice for newcomers to move into then relatively affordable housing.  Oceanside continues to be known for the value and appreciation as a vacation home market.During the 2010s
column14: several mid rise and high rise housing and lodging projects have been completed in the downtown area
column15: with more to come. In 2021 two large Hyatt resorts are scheduled to be completed
column16: bringing more tourists to the city.

column2: Oceanside is the last city before Orange County. As the crow flies
column3: it is roughly the same distance from Aliso Viejo as it is to downtown San Diego.

column1: Oceanside experiences a semi-arid climate (Köppen climate classification BSh) that is significantly tempered by maritime winds and the cool currents off the shoreline. The average high temperatures range from 64 °F (18 °C) to 77 °F (23 °C)
column2: while the average low temperatures range from 45 °F (7 °C) to 64 °F (18 °C).

column1: Oceanside hosts The Beach Soccer Championships since 2007. The festival is the largest on the west coast and takes place the third weekend in May. The event has a PRO side to the event called The Beach Soccer USA Cup and it is considered to host the toughest competition of its kind in the USA.

column1: The city operates under the council-manager form of government.  The city council consists of four members elected from districts and one mayor elected at large.  The City of Oceanside is a full-service city.  It provides its own police and fire safety
